title: Earl of Liverpool
text:
Earl of Liverpool is a title that has been created twice in British history. The first time was in the <a href="Peerage%20of%20Great%20Britain">Peerage of Great Britain</a> in 1796 for <a href="Charles%20Jenkinson%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">Charles Jenkinson, 1st Baron Hawkesbury</a>, a favourite of King <a href="George%20III%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">George III</a> (see <a href="Jenkinson%20baronets">Jenkinson baronets</a> for earlier history of the family). He had already been made Baron Hawkesbury, of Hawkesbury in the County of Gloucester, in 1786, and succeeded as the seventh Baronet of Walcot and Hawkesbury in 1790. His eldest son, the <a href="Robert%20Jenkinson%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">second Earl</a>, served as <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prime Minister of the United Kingdom</a> from 1812 to 1827. The peerages became extinct in 1851 on the death of the latter's half-brother, the <a href="Charles%20Jenkinson%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">third Earl</a>, while the baronetcy was inherited by a cousin (see <a href="Jenkinson%20baronets">Jenkinson baronets</a>).
The earldom was revived in 1905 in favour of the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> politician <a href="Cecil%20Foljambe%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">Cecil Foljambe, 1st Baron Hawkesbury</a>, son of George Foljambe and his second wife Lady Selina Charlotte Jenkinson, daughter of the third Earl of the first creation. He was made Viscount Hawkesbury, of Kirkham in the County of York and of Mansfield in the County of Nottingham, at the same time, and had already been created Baron Hawkesbury, of Haselbech in the County of Northampton and of Ollerton, Sherwood Forest, in the County of Nottingham, in 1893. His eldest son, the <a href="Arthur%20Foljambe%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">second Earl</a>, served as <a href="Governor-General%20of%20New%20Zealand">Governor-General of New Zealand</a> between 1912 and 1920. , the titles are held by the latter's great-nephew, the <a href="Edward%20Foljambe%2C%205th%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">fifth Earl</a>, who succeeded his great-uncle, the fifth son of the first Earl, in 1969. He is the posthumous son of Captain Peter George William Savile Foljambe (1919–1944), who was killed in action in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, son of the Hon. Bertram Marmaduke Osbert Savile Foljambe (1891–1955), sixth son of the first Earl. Lord Liverpool is one of the ninety elected <a href="hereditary%20peer">hereditary peer</a>s that remain in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a> after the passing of the <a href="House%20of%20Lords%20Act%201999">House of Lords Act 1999</a>, and sits on the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> benches.
Family estate and North Yorkshire roles.
The 4th Earl was Inspector of Driffield Division of the police's East Riding Special Constabulary, 1926–1945. He was returned by the people to <a href="Norton%20Rural%20District%20%28Yorkshire%29">Norton Rural District</a> in Yorkshire from 1927 to 1947. He had his main home published as Inverey, 11 West Park Road, <a href="Cupar">Cupar</a>, Fife, Scotland.
Earl of Liverpool, second creation.
Earl of Liverpool (1905).
The <a href="heir%20apparent">heir apparent</a> is the latter's son, Luke Marmaduke Peter Savile Foljambe, Viscount Hawkesbury (born 1972).
